choices.text: Dilated bowel loops with visible haustrations
Multiple dilated bowel loops with flatulence and increased bowel sounds
Dilated bowel loops with plica circularis

questions.text: Which of the following finding is a definite finding of "complete large bowel obstruction"?
questions.solution:
A LBO occurs when there is occlusion of the lumen of the colon anywhere along its course and dilatation of the large bowel proximal to the site of obstruction.

In the setting of LBO, the colon is dilated proximal to the site of obstruction with a paucity or absence of gas distal to the obstruction. The large bowel loops are located peripherally, usually measure more than 5 cm in diameter and display haustral markings that are incomplete, 2-3 mm wide and occurring at intervals of 1 cm.

Air-fluid levels are often seen in the dilated colon on the upright or decubitus radiographs. The presence of air-fluid levels suggest that the cause of obstruction is more acute since the colonic fluid has not been present long enough to be absorbed.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

small intestine obstruction- diameter >3cm

Large intestine obstruction >6cm

Caecal obstruction diameter >9 cm

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2079

choices.text: Fast assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.solution:
Sonography is commonly used for the initial assessment of abdominal trauma. Abdominal ultrasound in cases of major trauma is usually performed with a FAST (Focussed Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) examination. It provides a fast overview of the abdomen to detect free fluid which indicates hemoperitoneum and visceral organ injury in this setting. The FAST scan should be completed within few minutes with an aim to primarily search for free intraperitoneal fluid and screen organs for injury.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2096

questions.text: This FAST image in a trauma patient denotes?
questions.solution:
Following standard views are recommended in FAST:

  • Transverse view of epigastrium to detect pericardial fluid and injury to left lobe of liver.
  • Longitudinal view of right upper quadrant for right lobe of liver, right kidney and Morison's pouch and perihepatic free fluid.
  • Longitudinal view of left upper quadrant for spleen, left kidney and perisplenic free fluid.
  • Longitudinal views of bilateral flanks to look for free fluid in paracolic gutters.
  • Transverse and longitudinal views of suprapubic region for urinary bladder and free fluid in pelvis and pouch of Douglas.
  • Bilateral longitudinal thoracic views for pleural effusion.

The given image shows free fluid in the hepatorenal pouch which is suggestive of positive FAST.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2096

There are limitations to the FAST examination regardless of protocol used. For the abdominal examination, detection of blunt mesenteric, bowel, diaphragmatic, and retroperitoneal injuries can be difficult, as well as isolated penetrating injury to the peritoneum.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2096

questions.text: A 16 year old patient presented with seizures. An MRI brain was done and revealed multiple such lesions in the brain. On MR Spectroscopy these lesions revealed elevated choline, alanine and lactate. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Cysticercosis is the commonest parasitic disease in humans caused by the worm Taenia solium. It is the most common cause of acquired epilepsy throughout the world.

There are four main stages :

  • vesicular: viable parasite with intact membrane and therefore no host
  • colloidal vesicular: parasite dies within 4-5 years 1 untreated, or earlier with treatment and the cyst fluid becomes turbid. As the membrane becomes leaky edema surrounds the cyst. This is the most symptomatic stage.
  • granular nodular: edema decreases as the cyst retract further; enhancement persists.
  • nodular calcified: end-stage quiescent calcified cyst remnant; no edema. Each stage has fairly distinctive imaging features although there is no sharp demarcation between later stages.

On imaging,

Vesicular

  • cyst with dot sign
  • CSF density/intensity
  • eccentric hyperintense scolex on Tl can sometimes be seen
  • no enhancement is typical, although very faint enhancement of the wall and enhancement of the scolex may be seen
  • no surrounding vasogenic edema

Colloidal vesicular

  • cyst fluid becomes macroscopically turbid reflected in altered imaging appearance:
    • CT: hyperattenuating to CSF
    • MRI Tl: hyperintense to CSF 2
  • surrounding edema
  • cyst and the wall become thickened and brightly enhances
  • scolex is seen early in the colloidal phase but gradually shrinks down and is harder to identify

Granular nodular

  • edema decreases
  • cyst retracts eventually becoming a small enhancing nodule
  • enhancement persists but is less marked

Nodular calcified

  • end-stage quiescent calcified nodule
  • no edema
  • no enhancement on CT
  • signal drop out on T2 and T2* sequences
  • some intrinsic high Tl signal may be present
  • long term enhancement may be evident on MRI and may predict ongoing seizures

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3520

questions.text: Which of the following stage of neurocysticercosis is not associated with edema on imaging
questions.solution:
Neurocysticercosis is caused by the CNS infection with the pork tapeworm Taenia solium, There are four main stages :

  • vesicular: viable parasite with intact membrane and therefore no host reaction.
  • colloidal vesicular: parasite dies within 4-5 years 1 untreated, or earlier with treatment and the cyst fluid becomes turbid. As the membrane becomes leaky edema surrounds the cyst. This is the most symptomatic stage.
  • granular nodular: edema decreases as the cyst retract further; enhancement persists.
  • nodular calcified: end-stage quiescent calcified cyst remnant; no edema. Each stage has fairly distinctive imaging features although there is no sharp demarcation between later stages.

On imaging,

Vesicular

  • cyst with dot sign
  • CSF density/intensity
  • eccentric hyperintense scolex on Tl can sometimes be seen
  • no enhancement is typical, although very faint enhancement of the wall and enhancement of the scolex may be seen
  • no surrounding vasogenic edema

Colloidal vesicular

  • cyst fluid becomes macroscopically turbid reflected in altered imaging appearance:
    • CT: hyperattenuating to CSF
    • MRI Tl: hyperintense to CSF 2
  • surrounding edema
  • cyst and the wall become thickened and brightly enhances
  • scolex is seen early in the colloidal phase but gradually shrinks down and is harder to identify

Granular nodular

  • edema decreases
  • cyst retracts eventually becoming a small enhancing nodule
  • enhancement persists but is less marked

Nodular calcified

  • end-stage quiescent calcified nodule
  • no edema
  • no enhancement on CT
  • signal drop out on T2 and T2* sequences
  • some intrinsic high Tl signal may be present
  • long term enhancement may be evident on MRI and may predict ongoing seizures

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3520

questions.text: A patient being mechanically ventilated in the ICU shows signs of worsening respiratory status. A CXR AP view done revealed the following appearance. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of pneumothorax as shown by visceral pleural line sign. In patients with pneumothorax, the visceral pleura is visible as a very thin line at the surface of the lung, with black air in the pleural space above or lateral to it, and air in the lung below or medial to it. Air may enter the fissure, outlining its pleural surfaces.

Reference: Thoracic Imaging, Third edition page no. 2134

questions.text: Patient presented with sudden onset difficulty in breathing, with RR 28 /min, normal blood pressure. X-ray is suggestive of unilateral hyperlucency with absent vascular markings and mediastinal shift to opposite side. The 1st step in the treatment of this patient would be ?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation-sudden onset difficulty in breathing, tachypnea (RR 28/min), unilateral hyperlucency with absent vascular markings on X-ray, and mediastinal shift to the opposite side-is highly suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

First Step in Management:

The immediate, life-saving intervention for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracotomy (needle decompression) to rapidly relieve pressure.

Correct Answer: (D) Needle thoracotomy

Explanation:

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space under pressure, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift.
This can rapidly cause hemodynamic instability and respiratory distress.

Needle thoracotomy (needle decompression) is performed as an emergency procedure to quickly release trapped air.

Definitive management after stabilization is ICD (intercostal chest drain) insertion, but the first step is needle thoracotomy.

Other Options:

(A) ICD insertion → This is the definitive treatment but takes longer. First, urgent decompression via needle thoracotomy is required.

(B) Endotracheal intubation → Intubation alone does not relieve the tension pneumothorax and can worsen the condition if positive pressure ventilation is applied before decompression.

(C) IV colloids → Fluid resuscitation is not the primary treatment, as the issue is not volume loss but pressure in the pleural space.

Reference: MacDuff A, Arnold A, Harvey JManagement of spontaneous pneumothorax: British Thoracic Society pleural disease guideline 2010 Thorax 2010;65:ii18-ii31.Question ID: 1216080

questions.text: This appearance seen on, M mode USG of thorax is suggestive of ?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound is now routinely used to detect pneumothorax in emergency settings.

A high frequency linear probe is used for analyzing superficial structures such as pleura. Patients are scanned in supine positions, with the probe placed on the anterior chest wall in a sagittal plane at the 2nd intercostal space in the mid clavicular line. M-mode is also used to detect this sliding movement. M-mode cursor is placed over the pleural line. The chest wall above the pleural line forms horizontal-the 'waves' and sliding pleural line forms a granular pattern-the 'Sand'. The resultant image of motionless chest wall and sliding pleura is seashore sign. Absence of lung sliding in presence of pneumothorax, visualized pleura will not be identified and movement of pleural line will not be present. The M-mode tracing will display one pattern of parallel horizontal lines above and below the pleural line. This is termed the 'barcode sign' or the 'stratosphere sign'.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2532

questions.text: A patient of RTA with injury over chest and limbs has low Spo2. M mode USG of the right upper part of the chest shows the Stratosphere sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Stratosphere sign (barcode sign) on M-mode ultrasound is highly specific for pneumothorax. It indicates absent lung sliding, which occurs when air in the pleural space prevents normal movement of the visceral and parietal pleura.

Key Diagnostic Features on M-mode USG:

  • Stratosphere Sign (Barcode Sign)
  • Seen in pneumothorax
  • Horizontal lines across the screen (like a barcode) instead of the normal "seashore" appearance
  • Seashore Sign (Normal Lung Sliding)
  • Upper part: Static (parietal pleura, chest wall) → looks like a sea surface
  • Lower part: Granular pattern (visceral pleura/lung movement) → looks like a sandy shore
  • Absent in pneumothorax, replaced by the barcode sign

Other Options:

(A) Hemothorax → Hemothorax would show fluid collection in the pleural space, detected as an anechoic area on USG (not Stratosphere sign).

(C) Cardiac Tamponade → Would show a pericardial effusion with collapsed right atrium/right ventricle on echocardiography (not related to lung ultrasound findings).

(D) Pulmonary Embolism → Would not cause a barcode sign; instead, right heart strain or DVT signs would be seen on imaging.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2532

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented with backache since 20 years and difficulty during neck movements. Most likely diagnosis based on this cervical spine radiograph is?
questions.solution:
DISH, often referred to as Forestier disease, is a common disorder found in the late middle aged/ elderly with an unknown etiology. It is characterized by marked hyperosteosis seen at multiple sites, but classically involving the spine. There is multilevel spinal involvement with flowing ligamentous ossifications.

The diagnostic criteria for DISH are:

  • Presence of ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies.
  • Preserved disc height
  • Absence of facet joint ankylosis or SI joint fusion.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic radiology, sixth edition, pg 1204

choices.text: GI suppression occurs at a higher radiation dose than that required for bone marrow suppression
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects
Bone marrow suppression occurs at 7.4 Gy

questions.text: True statement regarding "Acute Radiation syndrome" all except?
questions.solution:
The acute radiation syndrome (ARS) occurs after whole-body or significant partial-body irradiation (typically at a dose of >1 Gy). ARS can involve the hematopoietic, cutaneous, gastrointestinal and the neurovascular organ systems either individually or in combination.

The classic syndromes are: hematopoietic (doses >2-3 Gy), gastrointestinal (doses 5-12 Gy) and cerebrovascular syndrome (doses 10-20 Gy). There is no possibility to survive after doses >10-12 Gy.

The phases of ARS are-prodromal: 0-2 days from exposure, latent: 2-20 days, and manifest illness: 21-60 days from exposure.

Reference: López M, Martín M. Medical management of the acute radiation syndrome. Rep Pract Oncol Radiother. 2011 Jul 13;16(4):138-46. doi: 10.1016/j.rpor.2011.05.001. PMID: 24376971; PMCID: PMC3863169.

questions.text: ERCP is indicated in all except?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography (ERCP) is considered as the gold standard for the diagnosis of CP because of its superior spatial resolution and its ability to depict the ductal system in distended state. Side branch abnormalities in early CP may be detected. ERCP is an invasive procedure and has inherent procedure-related complications; hence this modality is mostly used with the intent of therapeutic interventions.

ERCP is also helpful in diagnosing other obstructive causes of CP such as ampullary lesions, intraductal neoplasms and congenital anomalies such as pancreatic divisum or annular pancreas

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2032

questions.text: Fish -tail deformity is seen after injury at which site?
questions.solution:
Fishtail deformity of the elbow is characterized by a contour abnormality of the distal humerus, which develops when the lateral trochlear ossification centers fail to develop or resorbs. It is a rare complication that can develop following a distal humeral fracture (e.g. supracondylar fractures, humeral condylar fractures) in childhood but can also develop with central physeal arrest.


Reference: Niknejad M, Knipe H, Rasuli B, et al. Fishtail deformity (elbow). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org https://doi.org/10.53347/rlD-21570

questions.text: A 60 year old chronic smoker presents with recurrent mild hemoptysis. A CXR PA view is normal and sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following tests will give the best diagnostic yield in this patient?
questions.solution: Reference: Seith Bhalla, Ashu & Goyal, Ankur & Guleria, Randeep & Kumar, Arun. (2015). Chest tuberculosis: Radiological review and imaging recommendations. The Indian journal of radiology & imaging. 25. 213-25. 10.4103/0971-3026.161431.
